metadata.sermon_title: The Word Moses Could Not Say
metadata.sermon_start_end: This verse has a missing word! I think of nowhere else in the sixty-six books of the Bible in which there is a word missing and a dash drawn to show that some unknown word or words ought to be where now this blank occurs. [...] I like to call his name. Sometimes when the world is tossing me like a ship upon the sea, I call that name, 'Jesus,' and he steadies me. 'Jesus my God, I know his name, ...His name is all my trust, He will not put my soul to shame Nor let my hope be lost.'

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon identifies a unique grammatical feature of the text (the aposiopesis/dash in Exodus 32:32). It attempts to find what is unique to this passage. However, it quickly pivots from the specific silence of Moses to a general Christological name-calling, losing the 'nowhere else' quality of the text's specific tension.
quotes: I think of nowhere else in the sixty-six books of the Bible in which there is a word missing and a dash drawn
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Resist the urge to fill the 'blank' too quickly with a general name. Explore the theological weight of the silence itself as it relates to the impossibility of atonement under the Law.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher provides a narrative reconstruction of the Sinai event. While it captures the drama, it lacks technical depth. The mention of 'Hebrew and Greek' requirements by Dekker is not met here; the exegesis is more illustrative than scholarly.
quotes: Moses, the lawgiver and liberator of Israel, is summoned by God to go up into Mt. Sinai
The sensory were satisfied, for the golden calf glistened in the desert sun.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the actual linguistic tension of the Hebrew text in verse 32, where the sentence is left hanging, to show the 'original' struggle of Moses.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is largely rhetorical and moralistic. It touches on the 'ghetto areas' and 'Martin King,' which provides some social context, but the application to the hearer remains at the level of 'shame' and 'worldly ambition' without specific contemporary analysis of the 'zeitgeist'.
quotes: How programs in our ghetto areas cry out for people who will put the lifting of their brothers and sisters above their own greed.
I will not stop to inquire if this depraved and debased condition of old Israel has not been reproduced by you and me
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond general 'worldly pleasures' to specific contemporary idols that function as the 'visible gods' Dekker warns about.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a traditional block structure: narrative retelling followed by a 'Now to the heart' transition. This separation makes the relevance feel like an afterthought rather than an inherent movement of the text.
quotes: Now to the heart and essence of what I am about this morning.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid 'bridge' sentences that signal the start of application. Let the exposition of the golden calf immediately 'expound' the hearer's current idolatry.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon strongly emphasizes misery (sin/idolatry) and redemption (Christ). It takes the 'misery' of the golden calf seriously. However, the 'gratitude' part is somewhat lost in emotionalism rather than ethical life.
quotes: Moses is dealing here with the profoundest question... sin and guilt and forgiveness.
I hang my head when I think of times when something else or someone else has seemed more precious to me
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Develop the 'gratitude' section by showing how the 'forgiven life' concretely responds to the grace found in the 'blank' of the text.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The preacher explicitly mentions being 'lost forever' and the 'gates of hell.' There is a sense of the seriousness of the human condition, though it leans more toward emotional regret than the 'ultimate possibilities of life design' Dekker describes.
quotes: The man's fiery earnestness makes him willing to be lost forever if Israel can be saved.
Jesus, who was our purchase price at the gates of hell?
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Connect the 'two ways' more to the hearer's current 'journey with a purpose' rather than just past sins.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the clear telos, but the sermon risks making 'Jesus' a magic word that fills a gap rather than the ontological solution to the Law's impasse. It borders on 'Jesus-logy' rather than a robust doctrine of the two natures.
quotes: I know the missing word. It is 'Jesus'
The word Moses could not speak is Jesus, for Moses lived too early
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure Christ is not just a 'name' to call upon for comfort, but the 'telos' who satisfies the justice/mercy tension mentioned earlier.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1450 words, the sermon lasts about 14-15 minutes. According to Dekker's Thesis 8, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for true depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical and contemporary analysis to reach the 20-minute threshold required for substantive homiletical work.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its length and its tendency toward general emotional application rather than concrete, humanities-informed analysis. It correctly identifies a unique textual feature but resolves the tension too quickly with a pietistic focus on the 'name of Jesus' rather than a rigorous exposition of the text's specific theological contribution.
strengths: Strong identification of the 'blank' in the text as a starting point.
Serious treatment of the 'misery' of idolatry.
Clear Christological focus as the goal of the message.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (under 20 minutes) to achieve necessary depth.
Application remains largely general and rhetorical rather than concrete.
Exegesis lacks the technical/historical rigor Dekker demands.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate homiletical address, but it is not yet a 'sermon' in the strict Dekkerian sense. It lacks the 'breadth' of 20 minutes and the 'concrete truth' of specific contemporary application, opting instead for general truths and emotional appeals.
